name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Furthermore, it did not punish Iran for its noncompliance. President Trump was right to leave the Iran Nuclear Deal!

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Grossi’s testimony underscores the fatal flaws in the Iran Deal. It did not have the teeth to hold Iran accountable, it failed to give the the IAEA unfettered access to undeclared sites in a timely manner consistent w/ its additional protocols.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: This means that under the Iran Deal, Iran wasn’t required to answer questions about the undeclared sites or give IAEA fulsome or timely access to these sites.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Grossi said that IAEA’s “additional protocol” for undeclared nuclear activity was applied only “provisionally” & “voluntarily” under the Iran Deal.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Iran also failed to provide the necessary explanation for the presence of nuclear material & impeded IAEA’s access to the locations. IAEA found evidence of use & storage of nuclear material &/or conduct of nuclear-related activities in at least 3 undeclared locations in Iran.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Grossi confirmed that while the Iran Deal was in place and before the U.S. withdrew, Iran failed to declare locations where nuclear material had been present in violation of the agreement and attempted to conceal that noncompliance.

tweet_text:

KY 6th District Congressman Andy Barr @RepAndyBarr on various topics ahead of Congress returning…

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: However, I also have the humility to acknowledge that Congress lacks the power to divest the President of his Commander-in-Chief authorities under Article II.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: As a Member of Congress, I believe I have a special duty to jealously guard legislative prerogatives, including the power to declare war, and to provide a check on Executive Branch overreach.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: This was in recognition of the slow pace and inefficiency of legislative proceedings under the Articles of Confederation.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Don’t forget the Framers of the Constitution specifically rejected a proposal that Congress be empowered to “make war” and implied power for the President to “repel sudden attacks.”

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Of course, that is precisely the scenario here involving the President’s decisive defensive strike against Soleimani in response to the attack on our Embassy.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Finally, according to the OLC, “if our Armed Forces otherwise lawfully stationed in a foreign country were fired upon and defended themselves, we doubt that such engagement in hostilities would be covered by the consultation and reporting provisions of the War Powers Resolution.”

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Furthermore, the War Powers Resolution applies only to the deployment of “significant” bodies of military personnel, and would not apply to a drone strike.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: And the War Powers Resolution, 50 U.S.C. 1541-48, does not limit the the President’s power to act without Congress.  At most, it merely imposes a reporting & consultation requirement on the President until Congress passes a concurrent resolution to terminate the military action.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: The courts have generally declined to review the exercise of such unilateral Executive power.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: …and his duty to take care that the laws be faithfully executed generally empower him to deploy the Armed Forces abroad without a declaration of war by Congress or other congressional authorization.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Specifically, the OLC has said that the President’s inherent, constitutional authority as Commander-in-Chief, his broad foreign policy powers…

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: …if the President determines that the action would be anticipatory self-defense or otherwise serves the interests of the United States — at least where the nature, scope and duration of the anticipated hostilities are limited.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: In recent years, the Justice Department’s Office of Legal Counsel (OLC) has opined that the Constitution authorizes the President, as Commander-in-Chief, to order military action without congressional permission…

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: But dating back to the Prize Cases in 1863, the Supreme Court has long held that the President may act without Congress to defend the nation.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: It is true that the Constitution gives Congress the sole power to declare war and the sole power of the purse to either fund or defund military action.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: To my colleagues complaining about the absence of explicit congressional authorization for the Soleimani strike, a helpful reminder: Article II, Section 2 of the Constitution provides: “The President shall be Commander in Chief of the Army and Navy of the United States.”

name: Rep. Andy Barr

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: We need to focus on maximum wages not minimum wages.  I want workers to earn a lot more than $15 per hour.  But to give that opportunity to as many workers as possible we need economic growth—not central planning from Washington.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text:
And less than 20 percent of workers who would see a wage increase under this bill actually live in households that earn less than the federal poverty line. 

We need to focus on policies that will increase wages for all workers, not just minimum wage workers.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text:
Also -

There are mountains of evidence that a higher federally mandated minimum wage leads to fewer workers hired.  Regardless, whether you are for or against raising the minimum wage, we have to stop thinking so small.  Less than 3% of American workers earn the minimum wage.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Republicans support higher wages, and I applaud those who are trying to create better pay for American workers. But raising the minimum wage is the wrong path. It is bad for Kentucky and bad our country.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: A minimum wage hike would have a negative impact on entry-level and part-time jobs, especially for those under the age of 25 just starting careers. It would result in $9 billion net reduction in family income. This would NOT help low-income families - it would hurt them.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: MYTH: Raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour will increase family income. FACT: Raising the minimum wage will reduce pay for many American families.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Under the Trump Administration, the economy has experienced sustainable and significant job creation. A $15 minimum wage hike would reverse these wins, resulting in roughly $3.7 million jobs LOST.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Today I voted against the Raise the Wage Act, a misguided attempt to increase income for workers, which would reduce jobs in the Kentucky. https://t.co/hWQzsGZrsx

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: I am committed to protecting individuals with pre-existing conditions which is why it’s important to look beyond the false name and understand H.R. 986 will not protect Americans but eliminate healthcare choices for states. #ForThePolitics

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: https://t.co/uss8GrnxAC

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Medicare for All = Medicare for None.  It would be devastating for people with pre-existing conditions as it would limit their access to life saving care. #ForThePolitics

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Today's vote on the so-called Protecting Americans w/ Preexisting Conditions Act is a guise for the Dems as they continue to push Medicare for All, eliminate insurance for 158 million Americans, & cost taxpayers more than $30 trillion. It's #ForthePolitics, not for the people.

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: I just voted again to require Congress to work with the Administration to protect Americans with pre-existing conditions, lower premiums, lower drug cost, and strengthen Medicare. My Democratic colleagues voted to proceed with the bill as is. Proof this bill is #ForthePolitics

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Republicans have voted repeatedly to protect Americans with pre-existing conditions including our first vote in 2019 - requiring the consideration of legislation that guarantees no American can be denied coverage or charged more because of pre-existing conditions. #ForThePolitics

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: RT @HouseCommerce: Democrats are playing politics by pushing a bill with a misleading title that has nothing to do with protecting people w…

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: These waivers work! Seven of the states that have created their own reinsurance programs under Section 1332 have seen lower premiums. On average, premiums have decreased 19.9% in the first year of enactment. #ForThePolitics

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: To be clear: the ACA pre-existing conditions provisions cannot be waived under section 1332.  These waivers give states flexibility to innovate, lower costs for all insured, including those with pre-existing conditions! #ForThePolitics

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: CMS Administrator Verma said: “Again, I want to make clear that a section 1332 waiver CANNOT undermine coverage for people with pre-existing conditions.”

name: Rep. Andy Barr
tweet_text: Do not judge a bill by its name! Today, the house will vote on the H.R. 986 – Protecting Americans with Pre-existing Conditions Act, however, despite the name, this bill does NOTHING to protect people with pre-existing conditions.
